title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenue. The service industry makes up 17 percent of these businesses, followed by the construction industry at 13.9 percent. The number of businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives grew significantly from 1992 to 1997, with their gross receipts also showing a substantial increase. This growth outpaced that of all businesses during the same period. The Small Business Development Center program has been found to be cost-effective, especially for clients receiving long-term counseling. The Small Business Development Center program is cost-effective, with clients generating additional tax revenues of $468,000,000 in 1998, six times the program's cost to the Federal Government. Small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians receiving services have a higher survival rate. Business counseling and technical assistance are provided. The Act aims to stimulate economies and foster economic development on Indian lands by providing critical business counseling and technical assistance, which has been shown to reduce default rates for lending programs. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands by fostering economic development, assisting in creating and expanding small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians, providing management and technical assistance, seeking advice from Tribal Councils, and ensuring full access to business opportunities. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands by fostering economic development and providing small business development assistance to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to ensure full access to business counseling and technical assistance. Small Business Development Center assistance is provided to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Small Business Act is amended to allow applicants in eligible states funded by the Administration as Small Business Development Centers to apply for an additional grant to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians with small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The Small Business Act is amended to allow eligible states with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to apply for grants to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Applicants must submit grant applications for assistance. The Small Business Act is amended to allow eligible states with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to apply for grants to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Grant applicants must submit applications detailing their goals and capabilities to provide training and services to a representative number of tribe members. The Small Business Act is amended to allow eligible states with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to apply for grants to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Grant applicants must provide training and services to tribe members, specify the location of the Small Business Development Center site, state the required grant funding amount, and demonstrate consultation with local Tribal Councils. The Small Business Act is amended to allow eligible states with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to apply for grants to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Grant applicants must comply with all requirements, receive a maximum of $300,000 in grants per fiscal year, and follow regulations after consulting with local Tribal Councils. The Small Business Act is amended to allow eligible states with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to apply for grants to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Grant recipients must comply with all requirements, receive a maximum of $300,000 in grants per fiscal year, and follow regulations issued by the Administration after consulting with local Tribal Councils. Regulations will establish standards for educational, technical, and support services to be provided. The Small Business Act is amended to allow eligible states with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members to apply for grants to support small business startups on Indian lands. Regulations will establish standards for services provided by Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance. The term 'Indian lands' is defined in this section, referencing definitions from various legal sources including the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. The term 'reservation' in the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 refers to Indian tribes as bands, nations, or organized groups of eligible individuals in the contiguous United States. The term 'Indian tribe member' refers to a member of an Indian tribe, excluding Alaska Natives. The term 'Alaska Native' is defined as 'Native' in the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term 'Native Hawaiian' is also mentioned. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to an individual who is a US citizen and a descendant of the aboriginal people who exercised sovereignty in Hawaii before 1778. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to a US citizen and descendant of the aboriginal people who exercised sovereignty in Hawaii before 1778. Tribal organization is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. $7,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2006-2008 for this purpose. $7,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2006-2008 for this purpose, with funding limitations specified. The Administration may only use appropriated amounts specifically for this paragraph. Section 21(c) of the Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers receiving grants to seek advice from tribal organizations on how to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.
